bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to J.W. Amesse, September 19, 1908

div1.p: Kean protests against the American quarantine of all Cuban ports.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to J.W. Amesse, September 19, 1908
div1.opener:
Havana, September 19th. 1908.
Dr. Amesse, Pass. Asst. Surgeon
Office of U.S. Marine Hospital Service
Havana.
Dear Sir:-
div1.p:
In reply to your letter of this morning I beg to
inform you that on the 16th. inst. at about 3 p.m. Mr. Pardiñas
was called from your office to the telephone and was requested
to inform me that “quarantine had been declared by the United
States against all the ports of Cuba”. Mr. Pardiñas avers that
he had asked whether the quarantine was really against all the
ports of Cuba and the same words were repeated.

No other notification having been received from you
during the next 24 hours, the National Board of Health, with
the approve of the Provisional Governor, was convened and passed
a resolution protesting before the Governor against such an
unjustificable measure.

It was only in the morning of the 18th. that your
letter confirming your telephone notification of the 16th. was
received, that letter having been apparently mailed the preced-
ing evening; but in this letter the word Havana was given
insteas of those sent by telephone (“all ports of Cuba”). I am
glad to know that the evil is not so great as at first appeared,
but I still hold that the quarantine even with this restrictions
should not be maintained, inasmuch as no secondary case or
suspect has developed in the twelve days that have elapsed
since the case at “Cuatro Nacion” and you must be fully aware
of the care with which all the prophyllactic measures and the
vigilance of nonimmunes have been carried out.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly Kean
Chief of Sanitation.
